Introduction

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a class of >20 medications widely used for their analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory effects.  They are among the most frequently prescribed and over-the-counter drugs globally and are used to manage conditions ranging from acute pain and fever to chronic inflammatory diseases (eg, rheumatoid arthritis).



NSAIDs achieve their pharmacologic effects primarily through the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, which are critical in the biosynthesis of prostaglandins, the lipid compounds involved in inflammation, pain, and fever.  Beyond the prostaglandin-mediated effects, NSAIDs may have additional poorly understood mechanisms involving transcription factors.  The therapeutic benefits of NSAIDs are counterbalanced by a range of potential adverse effects, most notably gastrointestinal (GI), cardiovascular, and renal complications.

Relevant pathophysiology



NSAIDs target the COX enzymes—COX-1 and COX-2—which catalyze the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandin H2 (

Arachidonic acid metabolic pathways
).  This intermediate compound is further broken down into various prostanoids, including prostaglandin D2/E2, prostacyclin, and thromboxane A2.  The 2 COX enzymes, which are discussed in more detail in a separate article, have distinct physiological roles:



  • COX-1:  This enzyme is constitutively expressed in most tissues and maintains normal physiologic functions, including gastric mucosal protection, platelet aggregation, and renal perfusion.
  • COX-2:  This inducible enzyme is upregulated in response to inflammatory stimuli such as cytokines and endotoxins.  It is the primary mediator of prostaglandin synthesis in inflamed tissues.


By inhibiting COX enzymes, NSAIDs reduce prostaglandin levels, resulting in an antiplatelet effect, reduced inflammatory responses, and relief of pain and fever.

Mechanism of action and class effects



NSAIDs exert their effects through the reversible inhibition of COX enzymes; however, this excludes aspirin, which irreversibly acetylates COX.  NSAID class effects include:



  • Anti-inflammatory effects:  Decreased vasodilation, vascular permeability, and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Analgesia:  Reduced peripheral and central prostaglandin-mediated pain signaling.
  • Antipyretic effect:  Inhibition of prostaglandin E2 synthesis in the hypothalamus, resetting the thermoregulatory set point.


Most NSAIDs (eg, ibuprofen, naproxen) are nonselective inhibitors of COX:  They inhibit both COX-1 and COX-2.  This dual inhibition provides therapeutic benefits (eg, reducing inflammation and pain) but increases the risk of adverse effects due to disruption of COX-1–mediated protective functions, particularly gastric mucosal protection.  In contrast, selective COX-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib) reduce inflammation while preserving COX-1–mediated protective functions (at the expense of increased cardiovascular risk, as discussed later).  NSAIDs with moderate COX-2 selectivity include meloxicam (at the lowest dose), nabumetone, diclofenac, and etodolac.

Clinical indications

Traditional NSAIDs



NSAIDs are used across a broad spectrum of clinical settings, including:



  • Acute pain and inflammation (headaches, minor trauma, postoperative pain, dysmenorrhea).
  • Musculoskeletal disorders (eg, chronic low back pain).
  • Rheumatologic conditions (eg, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis).
  • Gout.
  • Osteoarthritis.

Aspirin



Aspirin is most often used in low doses (eg, 81 mg) for atherosclerotic disease, including coronary artery disease, intracranial and carotid artery stenosis, and peripheral arterial disease.  At these doses, aspirin mainly targets COX-1 to reduce production of thromboxane A2 by platelets; this antiplatelet effect lasts the duration of the platelet lifespan (eg, a week) due to the irreversible nature of this COX inhibition.  Higher aspirin doses (eg, 650 mg to 4 g), although less commonly used than traditional NSAIDs, have broader COX inhibition with the addition of analgesic and antipyretic effects due to reduced prostaglandin production.

Adverse effects



NSAIDs carry significant risks for adverse effects, particularly with chronic use or in high-risk populations.  Multiple NSAIDs should not be used simultaneously; the exception is low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular protection.

Gastrointestinal



NSAIDs reduce protective prostaglandins in the gastric mucosa, predisposing to adverse GI effects, including dyspepsia, gastritis, bleeding, and peptic ulcers (

figure 2
).  Mechanisms include:



  • Increased gastric acid formation.
  • Decreased mucosal bicarbonate production.
  • Decreased mucosal blood flow.


Piroxicam has a particularly high GI toxicity risk and is typically reserved for when other NSAIDs have failed.  Selective COX-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib) have the lowest GI toxicity risk but carry increased cardiovascular risk.



Risk factors for adverse GI events include age >65, long-term use or high-dose therapy, prior ulcer history, and concurrent use of medications with additive risk (eg, corticosteroids, anticoagulants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors).  In these cases, COX-2 selective medications should be used when possible.  Alternately, proton pump inhibitors or misoprostol may be used to protect the gastric lining, although concurrent use of low-dose aspirin negates this benefit.

Cardiovascular



NSAIDs predispose patients to adverse cardiovascular events, including:



  • Hypertension.
  • Heart failure exacerbation.
  • Myocardial infarction.


Hypertension and heart failure exacerbation can occur due to volume overload caused by decreased renal production of prostaglandin E2 and prostacyclin, which normally promotes natriuresis, diuresis, and renal vasodilation.  Myocardial infarction risk is particularly notable with COX-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib; rofecoxib, now withdrawn from the market) because COX-2 leads primarily to prostacyclin production (vasodilatory and antithrombotic).  Meanwhile, COX-1, which predominantly generates thromboxane A2 (vasoconstrictive and prothrombotic), remains active, increasing thrombotic risk.  Among NSAIDs, naproxen is associated with the lowest risk due to balanced COX-1 and COX-2 inhibition, although its use should still be limited.

Renal



NSAIDs can cause renal complications such as acute kidney injury, fluid retention, and electrolyte disturbances (eg, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia).  Under normal conditions, prostaglandins dilate the afferent arteriole, maintaining adequate renal perfusion and glomerular filtration rate (GFR).



NSAIDs block prostaglandin-mediated dilation, leading to constriction of the afferent arteriole, reduced renal blood flow, decreased GFR, and reduced sodium excretion (

figure 3
).  In healthy patients, prostaglandin synthesis is low and NSAID use has minimal effects on renal hemodynamics.  However, NSAID use should be avoided in patients with reduced effective arterial blood volume (eg, volume depletion, heart failure, cirrhosis), in which renal blood flow is highly dependent on prostaglandins.



NSAIDs also reduce renin-mediated aldosterone secretion, impairing potassium excretion and increasing the risk of hyperkalemia.  Moreover, diminished prostaglandin activity enhances antidiuretic hormone activity, contributing to dilutional hyponatremia.

Hematologic



Aspirin irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation through COX-1 blockade, prolonging bleeding time.  Other NSAIDs cause reversible platelet inhibition, also increasing bleeding risk, particularly in patients concurrently using anticoagulants.  Bleeding occurs in the absence of detectable laboratory abnormalities with the exception of an abnormal bleeding time.

Hepatic



NSAIDs, particularly sulindac, can cause asymptomatic elevations in liver enzyme levels, although liver failure is rare.  Diclofenac has been associated with idiosyncratic hepatitis.  NSAIDs should specifically be avoided in patients with cirrhosis due to the risk of variceal hemorrhage, kidney dysfunction, and the development of diuretic-resistant ascites.

Special considerations

Route of administration



NSAIDs are typically administered orally but are also available parenterally via intravenous and intramuscular injections, as well as topical formulations (eg, diclofenac gel).  Parenteral formulations offer rapid-onset analgesia and are typically used in acute hospital settings or when oral administration is not feasible (eg, vomiting); however, they carry risks similar to those of oral formulations.



Topical NSAIDs provide targeted pain relief with minimal systemic exposure, significantly reducing risks of GI, cardiovascular, and renal complications.  This makes them particularly suitable for localized musculoskeletal pain and arthritis.

Drug interactions



NSAIDs interact with various medications, potentially elevating serum levels of methotrexate, quinolones, and lithium (sulindac has the least impact on lithium levels).  Use with antiplatelet agents or anticoagulants increases bleeding risk.  NSAIDs can also cause hyperkalemia and reduce antihypertensive effectiveness when used with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers and can diminish diuretic efficacy.  Aspirin should specifically be avoided in individuals with asthma, nasal polyps, and a history of respiratory reactions related to NSAIDs (Samter triad) (

figure 4
).

Pregnancy and peripartum



NSAIDs should be avoided during the third trimester due to risks, including oligohydramnios and premature closure of the fetal ductus arteriosus.  Conversely, when the ductus arteriosus fails to close naturally after delivery, NSAIDs may be intentionally administered within 14 days of birth to promote closure.  In addition, NSAID use can impair female fertility by inhibiting ovulation; therefore, caution is advised in women attempting conception.

Miscellaneous



NSAIDs can occasionally lead to renal complications, including nephrotic syndrome, acute interstitial nephritis, and analgesic nephropathy with papillary necrosis (when used with acetaminophen chronically).  Rare dermatologic hypersensitivity reactions include Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis.  Indomethacin, specifically, is associated with CNS adverse effects such as headache, dizziness, and confusion.  NSAIDs may worsen inflammatory bowel disease through inhibition of protective mucosal prostaglandins.  Long-term aspirin use may be protective against colorectal cancer, possibly by reducing prostaglandin-mediated tumor growth; however, routine use for this indication is not routinely recommended.

Summary



Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are widely used medications for their analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties, primarily exerted through the inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2).  They are used for acute pain, musculoskeletal injuries, autoimmune disease, gout, headaches, and dysmenorrhea.  Adverse effects can be significant and encompass gastrointestinal ulcers, bleeding, cardiovascular complications, and renal injury.  Special caution is needed in high-risk populations such as elderly patients, individuals with preexisting cardiovascular or renal conditions, pregnant women, and people taking interacting medications (eg, corticosteroids, anticoagulants).



Nonselective NSAIDs (eg, ibuprofen, naproxen) inhibit both enzymes, notably predisposing to gastrointestinal complications (eg, ulcers, bleeding).  Selective COX-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib) minimize gastrointestinal adverse effects but at the expense of increased cardiovascular risks (due to unopposed thromboxane A2 action).  Aspirin uniquely provides irreversible COX-1 inhibition at low doses, which is beneficial for cardiovascular protection through sustained antiplatelet activity.
